title: Will North Korea launch a land based missile with the capacity to reach Alaska, Hawaii, or the continental United States before 1 January 2017?
preds: Many reports are that NK has already done this. The there are 2 questions here (a) did the missile have that range (b) are they planning another one. It seems probable that the answer to (a) is yes. The answer to (b) is that they are unlikely to do another trial this year

with the latest launch of a satellite if we believe the comments like the one from CNN, than that was it!
But NK has launched before a satellite into orbit  and it was not considered a long range missile.  Now lets see what the experts are saying after having analyzed the entire story including the debris fished out of the sea. I am only increasing my judgement to 80% because i judge the result a bit different than many of my colleagues herein the gjp. However I also trust that the likelihood is given that NK will test-launch more missiles during this year.
Why is this question still open?
Upping the probability, only question left is wether it was a missile with sufficient range. Although accuracy will still be bad.
It seems very likely North Korea may  have a long range missile capable of "Possibly" having a range capability of reaching Hawaii  or the Alaska Island chain.

Experts are unsure how much progress North Korea is making with its nuclear-weapons project. North Korea’s boasting is certainly no guide. For example, it is highly unlikely that the detonation in January involved a hydrogen bomb, which is more powerful than the atomic sort. The seismic signature of the test, in an underground complex near the border with China where earlier ones were conducted, suggested the device was similar in size to the one used in the previous test in 2013. At most, experts say, North Korea tested a “boosted-fission” device that uses an additive to achieve a bigger bang

This is a heads up. I apologize for not providing the specific reference, but I would like to call your attention to something that I read from 38North. That is, not too long ago they published an analysis that described how North Korea has likely changed design of their long-range ballistic missile. In short, it was how they changed from a 3-stage to a 2-stage design. If you read their detailed report, beside estimating that the newer design would not be available for operational deployment until around 2020, they also (and here's the important point) made an estimate on how long it would take to actually begin testing of the newer design. As I recall, this estimate was beyond the horizon of this question. So, to answer this question affirmatively, you are, under at least my interpretation, going against the estimate provided by 38North. I'm going against their estimate not because I know it is wrong, only because I think that North Korea might possibly have multiple designs in-the-works, or is re-purposing portions of the old design into the new one, or something along those lines. The primary motivation for this is the spate of construction improvements at their primary launch facility (as reported even earlier by 38North), completed late last year. I do not see why these launch facility modifications would be completed in late 2015 if the earliest they would be needed was not until 2017. I would encourage you to access the 38North report and read their words as to the estimate of earliest testing of the new design, and make up your own minds.

****North Korea carried out a submarine ballistic missile test launch Nov. 28***, Yonhap news agency just reported (citing South Korean government sources). The test appears to have been a misfire with only fragments of a safety cover spotted by observers. The South Korean Defense Ministry declined to comment on the report. In May, North Korea successfully tested a submarine-launched ballistic missile, but is still far from possessing the necessary submarine technology to deploy this capability. Fully developing this technology would extend the reach of North Korean nuclear missile systems and improve the country's second-strike capability in case its ground-based facilities are taken out.

This forecast is particularly difficult. North Korea almost always inflates its military arsenal and capabilities making basic assumptions concerning their technical capacities all the more difficult to assess, even for the IC. Two technical aspects need to be unpacked if an accurate estimation is to be given provided the constraints of open and dated information; i) Does NK have a land-based missile(s)?, and ii) do any of these 'land-based missile(s)' have the theoretical capability to reach Alaska/Hawaii/continental US? The first question can be answered with a high degree of certainty according to various open sources. The second question appears to be answered, but only slightly. According to the Center for Arms Control & Non-Proliferation' Fact Sheet, NK is alleged to have a medium-range missile capable of reaching the continental US (Taepodong-1 and/or Rodong / Nodong-1). The missile was tested in 1998 with partial success. But the Taepodong-2 is currently under development with the capacity to reach any of the stated countries and was tested five times between 2006 -2013 (as noted by @sanxiyn). @sanxiyn gives a high forecast of 75% (w/ justification), but this does not take into account varying changes in geopolitical relationships which could change the regime's calculus in the meantime. NK has publicly stated its desire to reach a peach settlement with the US, however NK did note that, "If the United States insists on taking a different path, the Korean peninsula will only see our unlimited nuclear deterrent being strengthened further." This I believe gives credence to @sanxiyn's high forecast, but China's recent disapproval of NK's missile testing over the years makes me think NK may lower their aggressive stance and re-frame from testing any missile (w/ the stated capability) over the next year.

I wish this question was asked more concisely. What happens if they test a missile intended to have the capacity to reach the continental US, but it fails mid-flight? Is that a "yes" or "no" answer to this question? I'm going on the assumption it is "yes", but it'd be nice if the question could be clarified. The phrase "capacity to reach" implies an extra hurdle whose context is not entirely clear (intended capacity? actual capacity? how do we know the actual capacity if the full range isn't tested? what if the technology is unproven due to a sea of Japan splashdown but the intent is there?). Given the link to the NYT article as subtext, I'm assuming the answer to my question is "yes", which is why I have 55%. DPRK loves to shake things up and stir trouble, and China doesn't have the leverage folks think. We have 1+ years left. That's plenty of time for the US and China to ignore the DPRK to focus on other things, and for the DPRK to throw a temper tantrum to prove to the world it's still relevant.

But If NK sees firing the missile as a symbol of its self-reliance to commemorate its 70th year anniversary of the party foundation, it will.

China and Russia are North Korea's only allies.  During China's Victory Day parade, Xi, Putin and South Korea's Park (North Korea's arch enemy) all sat/stood together, quite buddy-buddy in the reviewing stand. Meanwhile North Korea's representative at this event, Choe Ryong Hae, was relegated to the back of the crowd at the reviewing stand, perhaps over 100 ft from the Dynamic Trio. A missile that can launch a satellite also can drop an equivalent payload anywhere on Earth, with slight adjustments for rotation of the Earth at the latitude of launch and angle of launch. Indeed, a satellite launch would be a more significant test of a military missile than just launching one that lands far away. Satellite launch requires both delta v and the precision to alter course once in space in order to achieve orbit.

The only NK land based missile that currently has the potential to reach the US is the Taepodong-2.  The last test of the Taepodong-2 took place in December 2012; previous tests occurred in July 2006, April 2009, and April 2012 (see [1]).  That's an average of about 840 days between missile launches (counting today as a dummy missile launch), which would suggest that there is a 43% chance of one before 2017.  I think that estimate is too high, because it doesn't take into account the long time since the last missile launch; 1500 days between launches seems like a better estimate.  With that number,  get a 27% chance, which seems about right.

Capability - They have missiles that are capable of meeting the resolution criteria.  Though a failed test launch would qualify with a YES resolution,  a failed test would be an embarrassment to the NK regime.  Thus any test requires the systems to be ready, and not necessarily "on demand"  as a show  of force during a crisis.  
Reason -  There are many; showing offensive and deterrent capability  as well as system testing. 
Restraints -  Their long time protector China and new best friend Russia would strongly frown on such activity.    
The NK regime will launch such a missile again it is just whether it happens in the next  16 months.   Even at a low 2% probability for any given month we get quickly to 32%  and then adjust down for time.
